Description: Corroded iron artefact in the shape of a conical rasp, grater or borer (?). Made of a piece of thin sheet of metal punched all over with small round holes and coiled round into a cone; originally fitted on a wooden handle.
Curator's comments: W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 78 § 78, p. 110, pl. xxxviii, 9; one of these "very curious rasps or borers", "made of a piece of thin sheet-iron, punched all over with holes like a modern grater, and coiled round into a cone; they have been found with string at the base, and fitted on to wooden handles, making a sort of rat-tail file or rasp; five were found, three of them in chamber 17". The Museum register also describes it as a possible strainer. Another one, also from Chamber 17, was in the BM collections (Num. 23973 - 1887,0101.1495) but remains not found. See also Boston, MFA, 87.519 (possibly Petrie, ibid., pl. xxxviii, 10).
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 78 § 78, p. 110, pl. xxxviii, 9)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.50, p.76-77, p.185, pl.27)
